text: I don’t use any of the Betcode stuff. But do you guys realise that there is an absolute maximum amount that can be won. You are all competing against each other. If <@U9JHLMZB4> wins more then <@U4H19D1D2> wins less etc.. It’s not like the stock market where everyone can win at same time.

text: Everyone can win at the same time when trading stocks? I'll not speak for anyone else here but pretty sure that anyone profitable realises they are in competition with everyone else in the markets. I don't see this as some great revelation. Nobody here promotes the notion that "everyone can win" from what I can tell - quite the opposite in fact.

text: In Vegas, for poker, there are professionals and then there are tourists. Professionals mostly don't eat each other up, the tourists who seek entertainment provide the poker tables endless action. It is the same with sports betting markets. This slack channel is mostly serious bettors, sure some alpha gets leaked but the point is to raise your game up. It is likely that @Peter <@U4H19D1D2> and myself can all collectively make more from the casual punters through open source code and idea sharing

text: Initially i was also surpised by how much liam provided given its a competition, but as of now, i m pretty sure he made a good deal with that. A group within can still heavily benefit from idea sharing and code sharing and in order to get actual meaningful help you also need to provide meaningful help. In such an enviroment some kind of trust needs to be established and from there on you surely can create relations that are helpful in both directions.

text: Sounds very pessimistic to me. Given the £M's traded on betfair daily, the sheer number of markets available and the plethora of strategies that can be deployed on each market, it's highly unlikely that we're all stepping on each others toes. Worst case is that we all play the same markets with different strategies/triggers and even then, we're all taking money from different spaces and situations. Fortunately, there are still a majority of punters and "traders" following YouTube tutorials that are feeding money into the ecosystem...

text:
When I meet people this seems to be question number 1, from profitable through to newbies. I always give the same answer which is that there is no way I would be where I am now without having worked with and spoken to those that I have met through open sourcing bflw/betcode.

You make the assumption that anyone who uses betcode libraries will make money, they are just tools. Open sourcing flumine was always a risk as its far more powerful than it lets on however it has pushed me (and others) to improve it, add features, fix bugs and is now 100x quicker than its predecessor.

The biggest change I have seen in the 'landscape' since this slack is the acceptance that you need to get value to make money. Its a secret world and think this slack is the closest you can see it in public other than the meetups :wink:

text:
_You make the assumption that anyone who uses betcode libraries will make money, they are just tools._ 

I've heard this so many times over the years. Most newcomers are very naive and assume that bot == profit but we all know that automating a shit strategy is just a more efficient shit strategy.
